Entries.default: "I've got all sorts goods and supplies. Take a look before you head back out."
"Farewell."
"Let's see what you've got for sale."
"Take a look."
"Why are you working at a Rauataian outpost?"
She chuckles. "Because I'm from Rauatai! "Or, to be more specific, my ancestral home's been part of the empire for decades. A few generations now."
"The usual way, I guess. Their soldiers beat ours." She shrugs.
"How did your homeland become part of Rauatai?"
"Doesn't that bother you?"
"What's it like, living under Rauataian rule?"
"I dunno. I've never known anything else."

She looks you up and down. Her eyes narrow with suspicion, and she hesitates.

Then, she adopts a careful, blank expression.
She glances around to see if anyone is in earshot.

"No. Of course not. Don't see why it would.

"There, uh, something else on your mind?"
"I guess it used to. When I was younger. I grew up hearing stories of the time before from my grandparents."

"Some wax romantic about the old days. Anyways, I'm just trying to make a living.

"That's why I'm here, after all."
"But they were children themselves when Rauatai took over." She frowns at you thoughtfully.

"We've got the Rauataians' fancy new irrigation canals now. And the roads have gotten better.

"The ones leading into TƒÅkowa, anyhow." She pauses, lost in thought, and smirks.
"Funny thing is, the further you go on them, the nicer everything gets. And the more it all looks like this." She nods at the stone walls and towers.
"Let's get back to business."
"That's a better subject." She smiles carefully.
"Hello there, [player race]! Say, you look like you're a long way from home." She smiles amiably.
"Hello there! Always nice to see another furry face around here." She winks at you.
"Hello th- oh!" She looks up at you and jumps.
"Sorry, you startled me a little." She blinks at your twisted visage, laughing with chagrin.
"You in the market for some supplies, friend?"
"I hope you don't mind me asking, but how do you get your shirts on in the morning?" She's staring at the horn-like protrusions on your head.
"Carefully."
"None of your business."
"You don't see me asking how you keep the fur off your clothes, do you?"
"I guess so." She nods slowly.
"Fair enough." She shrugs.
